body:
I agree alot with having a tuple output, and also agree with the idea of calling sum on the tuple output if need be. We need to be careful about erroneously counting order 2 scattering coefficients when there arent any; a test can provide a check of correctness. 

I don't believe we should add a error message.
So should we keep accommodating both `self.output_size(detail=True)` and `self.output_size(detail=False)` ?

That's a breaking change, but OK. It will cause this in user code:

> self.output_size(detail=True)
> TypeError: output_size() got an unexpected keyword argument 'detail'

@MuawizChaudhary shouldn't we produce a more helpful error message?

If you think its a good idea, we can add a error message stating that we removed `detail=True`. 

I wouldn't expect many users to have used `self.output_size`. however. Personally, I think we should have a variable in `Scattering1D` that holds the size of the scattering, and this variable should be named `num_coefficents` or something like that. 

That is, I dont think we should even have this be a user exposed function.

> If you think its a good idea, we can add a error message stating that we removed detail=True.

Then, i suggest we go with the breaking change, release v0.3, and if anyone complains about `output_size() got an unexpected keyword argument 'detail'`, i'll write a helpful error message for v0.3.1. Deal?


> Personally, I think we should have a variable in Scattering1D that holds the size of the scattering, and this variable should be named num_coefficents or something like that. That is, I dont think we should even have this be a user exposed function.

I disagree. If it's a variable in the state of the program, then potentially people can modify/delete it, which will lead to antipatterns and strange hacks. Whereas making it the return value of a method (`self.output_size()`) prevents that problem. I see this method as a "getter" on a private field.

issue.title: `self.output_size()` (always `detail`-ed), introduce `self.num_coefficients`

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
Fixes #838 

* `precompute_size_scattering` now always returns a tuple
* same for `self.output_size()` in `Scattering1D`
* introduce read-only property `self.num_coefficients` to replace the old `self.output_size(detail=False)`
* fewer LOCs for `precompute_size_scattering`

This PR will conflict with #837 in the `if self.vectorize:` statements. #837  should take precedence

body:
> Then, i suggest we go with the breaking change, release v0.3, and if anyone complains about `output_size() got an unexpected keyword argument 'detail'`, i'll write a helpful error message for v0.3.1. Deal?

Sounds good to me.



> I disagree. If it's a variable in the state of the program, then potentially people can modify/delete it, which will lead to antipatterns and strange hacks. Whereas making it the return value of a method (`self.output_size()`) prevents that problem. I see this method as a "getter" on a private field.

Yes let's not mix styles here. We already have `meta` as a function, so the same should be true of `output_size`. I see @MuawizChaudhary's point about the need for the function (technically all the information is already in `meta`), but it's still useful to have as a shorthand for `len(scattering.meta)` or something similar.
So just to make sure I've got this right, `precompute_size_scattering` will fix `detail=True` and `output_size` will fix `detail=False`?

> So just to make sure I've got this right, precompute_size_scattering will fix detail=True and output_size will fix detail=False?

Yes, that's what we just said ... but that would remove useful functionality, namely the `out_size(detail=True)` non-default. So i'm no longer in favor of it (at first, i believed that `out_size()` was currently `detail`-ed by default, but the opposite is true)

Looking back at it, i don't think there's much to be done here, except maybe removing the confusing `detail` keyword argument from `precompute_size_scattering`, and doing the summation inside `out_size`. This will be fully backwards compatible and will reduce the number of conditional branches in unit tests.

issue.title: `precompute_size_scattering` now returns a tuple

repository.name: kymatio
repository.description: Wavelet scattering transforms in Python with GPU acceleration

issue.body:
no more `detail` kwarg
fixes #838

came up in conversation with @janden and @MuawizChaudhary : https://github.com/kymatio/kymatio/issues/838#issuecomment-1151084298
